results.title: Angelica Mesiti: The Calling interview
results.creator_credit: Jesse Taylorsmith, Kim Montgomery, Shelley Matulick, ACMI and Ian Potter Cultural Trust
results.brief_description:
In this interview (filmed as part of activities associated with the ACMI Exhibition ‘Angelica Mesiti: The Calling’) the artist reflects on the structure, approach and the processes involved in creating the work.

‘The Calling’ is a three channel video installation that focuses on whistling languages, ancient forms of non-verbal communication which are still used in 2013 to communicate in isolated and difficult landscapes.

To conduct research for ‘The Calling’, artist Angelica Mesiti travelled to the village of Kuskoy in Northern Turkey, the island of La Gomera in The Canary Islands and the Island of Evia in Greece where whistling languages are still in use.

results.title: Moon to Dust
results.creator_credit: Kanlaya Padungsin and Animation and Interactive Media (AIM) RMIT
results.brief_description: Winner of ‘Best Character Animation’ for RMIT’s AIM Graduate Screenings, 2009. Set to the song of the same name by Georgia Fields, ‘Moon to Dust’ is a beautiful and melancholic rendering of belonging, isolation and change.

results.title: The Lost Thing
results.creator_credit: Andrew Ruhemann, Shaun Tan, Leo Baker, Sophie Byrne and Passion Pictures
results.brief_description: Set in a city overrun by bureaucracy, this Oscar Award winning animated short film of Shaun Tan’s picture book ‘The Lost Thing’, tells the story of a boy who befriends a strange creature that doesn’t appear to fit in any of the available pigeonholes.

results.title: From Jean-Paul Sartre to Teresa Teng: Cantonese Contemporary Art in the 1980s
results.creator_credit: Clair Hsu, Jane DeBevoise, Arts Asia Archive and Siren Films
results.brief_description:
Interviews with leading Cantonese artists and their memories of a developing art scene in the 1980s.

“The 1980s was a seminal period in the history of contemporary art in China. However, the contribution and experimentalism of the art scene in South China, in particular, Guangzhou and Shenzhen, have generally been overlooked. Due to the proximity of Hong Kong, western ideas from translated books and articles, as well as popular culture in the form of TV shows and Canto pop, flooded over the border to Guangdong at the end of the Cultural Revolution. This influx of new ideas and popular culture sparked great excitement, debate and experimentation in the arts.

Based on primary research, rare film footage and personal interviews with key artists, this documentary bears witness not only to the reading fever that gripped the Chinese art world in the 1980s, but also highlights the experimentalism and verve of artists and critics in South China whose contributions to the development of contemporary art have been long lasting and fundamental.” Source: Arts Asia Archive [www.aaa.org.hk]

Interviewees include: Chen Shaoxiong, Chen Tong, Deng Jianjin, Feng Yuan, Hou Hanru, Huang Xiaopeng, Li Zhengtian, Lin Yilin, Shao Hong, Wang Du, Wang Huangsheng, Xu Tan, Yang Jiechang and Yang Xiaoyan.
results.title_for_label: From Jean-Paul Sartre to Teresa Teng: Cantonese Contemporary Art in the 1980s

results.title: [Cinesound Review: Royal Tour Concludes]
results.creator_credit: William M. Carty, Cinesound and Peter Bell
results.brief_description:
This film is a Cinesound Review, a news broadcast that covered significant social, cultural and political events in Australia. The newsreel shows the final leg of the 1970 Royal Tour with Queen Elizabeth II, Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh and Princess Anne, for the bicentenary celebrations of the arrival of Captain James Cook in Australia in 1770.

The film shows the royal family arriving in Brisbane, Queensland, on the Royal Yacht Britannia, where they are greeted by crowds of people in hundreds of boats on the river. It shows the family attending various events, including a welcome at Parliament House, theatre shows and a children’s parade at Lang Park, or Brisbane Stadium.

Princess Anne visits a sheep station at Cunnamulla, Queensland, while Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip visit the mines at Mount Isa, Queensland.

The film shows bicentenary celebrations in Cooktown, Queensland, and Botany Bay, New South Wales. These celebrations include a speech by the Queen and re-enactments of Captain James Cook’s arrival in Australia in 1770, with interactions with Aboriginal Australian people.

The film continues with fireworks over Sydney Harbour; an ANZAC Day march in Canberra, Australian Capital Territory; Prince Philip playing polo with a local team; and the opening of the international terminal at Sydney Airport, from which the royal family departs.

results.title: Miss Fisher's Murder Mysteries: Costume Designer Marion Boyce
results.creator_credit: Deb Cox, Fiona Eagger, Every Cloud Productions and Screen Australia
results.brief_description:
Meet Marion Boyce, costume designer for ‘Miss Fisher’s Murder Mysteries’ as she discusses some of the process involved in recreating the look and feel of the 1920s for the popular television series.
Boyce muses on the “sumptuous elegance” of fashion in the nineteen twenties, a period she describes as one of “extreme excess in a lot of ways …. they lived a lot with gay abandon”. She highlights the flattering silhouette bestowed by 1920s men’s fashion of the time, dwells lovingly on the exotic and embellished fabrics of the time, and talks about the use of original pieces - buckles, shoes, feathers and furs - to heighten the authenticity of the costumes.

results.title: Miss Fisher's Murder Mysteries: Cocaine Blues (Series 01. Ep. 01)
results.creator_credit: Tony Tilse, Deb Cox, Fiona Eagger, Every Cloud Productions and Screen Australia
results.brief_description: The Honourable Miss Phryne Fisher disembarks the Orient at Victoria Dock, returning to Melbourne after years abroad. Almost as soon as she checks into the Windsor Hotel, Phryne is embroiled in mystery: poisoned husbands, cocaine smuggling rings and illegal abortionists – not to mention erotic encounters with the handsome Russian dancer, Sasha de Lisse. Her adventure reaches its steamy end in the Turkish Bath Palace off Little Lonsdale Street. [Source: Every Cloud Productions]

results.title: Stories of Rippon Lea Estate
results.brief_description:
Melbourne’s historic Rippon Lea Estate is one of the fabulous locations used in the popular ‘Miss Fisher’ television series. It has also been the venue for an exhibition of the costumes from the series.
Here, staff of the National Trust of Australia (Victoria), who manage the property, talk about its history, its use as a filming location, and the relationship between the producers of the series, the National Trust, and the enthusiastic audiences for the series who have also visited Rippon Lea and the exhibition.

results.title: Miss Fisher's Murder Mysteries: Murder Under the Mistletoe (Series 02. Ep. 13)
results.creator_credit: Tony Tilse, Deb Cox, Fiona Eagger, Every Cloud Productions and Screen Australia
results.brief_description: Phryne, Dot and Dr Mac happily accompany Aunt Prudence to a picturesque chalet to celebrate a white Christmas in July. The party arrives to find one of the residents dead – electrocuted while hanging festive lights. No more suspicious than the usual Miss Fisher investigation, until the body count starts to rapidly rise. Heavy snowfalls and harsh weather trap them all with a murderer in their midst – and any one of them the next victim. It’s a race against time for Phryne and Jack to hunt down the culprit – and restore enough Christmas joy to take full advantage should they find themselves standing under that bunch of that mistletoe! [Source: Every Cloud Productions]
results.title_for_label: Miss Fisher’s Murder Mysteries: Murder Under the Mistletoe (Series 02. Ep. 13)

results.title: Miss Fisher's Murder Mysteries: Hispano Suiza
results.creator_credit: Deb Cox, Fiona Eagger, Every Cloud Productions and Screen Australia
results.brief_description:
Learn more about the luxury motor car that appears in the series, Phryne’s red ‘Hispano-Suiza’.
One of the luxury cars of the 1920s, the ‘Hispano-Suiza’ was favoured by royalty, film stars and moguls. The name means “Spanish Swiss”, but the car was manufactured in France, as explained by its owner, Bob, who spent twelve years restoring what had been “just a heap of rusty bits”. His successful restoration adds an authentic glamour to Phryne’s motoring.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Deb Cox, Fiona Eagger, Every Cloud Productions and Screen Australia
